The Story of King Udayana (116) The Story of King Udayana. In the past, King Udayana lived in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha. He was intelligent, knowledgeable, and had great wisdom.
His first wife was named LÄvaá¹‡yavatÄ«. She was exceptionally beautiful and also virtuous. The king loved and respected her deeply, with the utmost affection.
At that time, it was the custom in that country that the king did not play the lute himself.
At that time, the wife, relying on the king's love and favor, said to the king:
Please play the lute for me and I will dance for the king.
The king, not wanting to refuse her request, took the lute and played it. The wife then raised her hands and danced.
The king, who was skilled at physiognomy, saw the signs of death in the wife's dance. He immediately put down the lute and sighed deeply with a somber expression.
The wife then said to the king:
As I am now, I receive the king's favor and dare to seek the king's qin in the curved room. I myself get up and dance to make music together. What is not suitable that you let go of the qin and sigh?
I wish the king not to conceal it but to tell me.
At that time, the king replied:
My long sigh is not something that you, a woman, can hear.
The wife said:
I now serve the king with utmost sincerity and without duplicity. If there is something improper, you should tell me.
Being persistent, the king truthfully replied:
How could I have any difference towards you?
When you danced just now, the signs of death were externally manifested. Calculating the remaining life, there are no more than seven days left. For this reason, I let go of the qin and sighed.
When the wife heard this, she was very worried and afraid. She said to the king:
As the king said, life is not far away.
I heard Bhikshuni Shi Shi say that if one can leave home with faith for even a day, they will definitely be reborn in the heavens.
For this reason, I wish to leave home. I hope the king will grant permission so that I can reach the path.
At that time, the king's feelings were heavy with affection and he did not let go. He said to the queen:
Wait until the sixth day, and then I will allow you to leave home and enter the path. I will not go against your intention.
Eventually, it reached the sixth day. The king said to the queen:
You have a good heart and wish to leave home. If you are reborn in the heavens, you must come to see me. Only then will I allow you to leave home.

After making this vow, the queen agreed and was then able to leave home. She received the eight precepts and observed the precepts. On that day, she drank a lot of sugar cane juice, which formed a lump in her stomach. On the morning of the seventh day, she immediately passed away.
By the power of this good cause, she was reborn in the heavens. She immediately had three thoughts:
First, she thought, What kind of body was I in my previous life?
Second, remember the original conditions and cultivate what merits?
Third, remember that the present body is definitely a heavenly body.
Having had this thought, fully know the original conditions and the vow with the king, and because of the previous vow, come to the king's place.
At that time, the light completely filled the king's palace. The king asked:
Whose auspicious light is this now?
Please show me.
The heavenly being replied:
I am the king's wife, the queen with auspicious marks.
The king heard this and said:
Please come and sit down.
The heavenly being replied:
As I am now, I see the king as foul-smelling and cannot approach him.
I came to see the king because of my previous vow.
Having heard this, the king's mind was enlightened, and he said:

That deity was originally my wife. Due to her wholesome mind, she sought to enter the path, left home for one day, and then passed away. Due to this merit, she was reborn in the heavens. Her spirit is lofty and far-reaching, yet she looks down on me.
Why don't I leave home now?
I have heard it said that the value of a single claw of a deity is equal to JambudvÄ«pa, let alone my entire country. What is there to be greedy and stingy about?
Having said this, he established his son, King Army, to succeed to the throne, left home to study the path, and attained arhatship.

At that time, King Army, having taken control of the country, trusted slander and did not care about state affairs. King UdÄyibhadra, feeling pity for his son and the people of the country, wanted to come and teach them, encouraging them to cultivate goodness.

At that time, the deceitful ministers, fearing they would be dismissed, said to the king:

If you welcome your father back to the throne, he will surely kill you. If you establish yourself, you must kill your father.

The father king replied:

He then extended his neck to over ten zhang, and said to the executioner:

At that time, the executioner, using the father king's order, told the king:

Having heard these words, he became even more despondent and said:
My father, the king, attained arhatship. What greed for the kingdom could have caused me to kill my father?
At that time, the deceitful minister, fearing that the king would punish him, said to the king:

The king believes empty words and brings suffering upon himself.

Having said this, he then created two holes in the stupa and placed a cat in each. He fed and raised the cats in the stupa, calling out Come out, Devadatta! The cats would come out to eat the meat, and when told to go back, they would return to the holes.

At that time, the Venerable was sitting in a crystal pavilion, with a radiant and lustrous spiritual appearance, without any soiled color. The minister joyfully bowed his head to the Venerable's feet and said to him:

The Venerable One replied:

When the great minister heard this, he was worried and distressed, and immediately reported it to the king;

When the seven days were over, the heavens rained down fragrant flowers, precious treasures, and garments. Everyone in the city was delighted. A flattering minister said to the king:
Now this auspicious sign is all due to the king's virtue. Ignorant people, on the contrary, slander, saying that it will rain earth, but they have obtained precious treasures.
Such deception has happened more than once. After the evil causes, hearing of the auspicious signs, they all come and gather like clouds.
At that time, by the power of past karma, the iron gates of the four city gates all closed, leaving nowhere to escape. The sky then rained down earth, filling the city with mountains of soil.
At that time, the minister who had the same intention as the Venerable One escaped through the underground passage and went to where the Venerable One was. He said to him:

' They then went together to the elder's house.

The Causes and Conditions of Rahula (117) The Causes and Conditions of Rahula I once heard that on the night when the Buddha first left home, the Buddha's son Rahula first entered the womb.

Siddhattha Bodhisattva practiced austerities for six years, and under the Bodhi tree, he subdued the four demons, removed all hindrances, suddenly had great enlightenment, attained supreme enlightenment, was fully endowed with the ten powers and four fearlessnesses, accomplished the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha, possessed the four kinds of eloquence, and reached the other shore in all the perfections. He understood all the teachings of the buddhas, surpassing all shravakas and pratyekabuddhas.
On the night of his initial enlightenment, Rahula was born. The entire palace and court ladies were all ashamed and greatly distressed, and said these words:
Alas, the great evil YaÅ›odharÄ, not considering right and wrong, lightly doing what should be done, not caring for herself, causing my entire palace to be defiled.
Siddhattha Bodhisattva has long since gone forth, and now suddenly giving birth to this child, it is a great disgrace.
At that time, there was a ÅšÄkya woman named ElekÄ, who was the daughter of YaÅ›odharÄ's aunt. She beat her chest and slapped her thighs, angrily scolding:
YaÅ›odharÄ!

Siddhattha Bodhisattva has great merit and his fame is widely known. Why do you now not protect and cherish him, but rather bring disgrace upon him?

At that time, King Åšuddhodana was in the pavilion. Seeing the great earth shaking in six ways and the appearance of strange signs, King Åšuddhodana, thinking that the Bodhisattva had died, an arrow of worry pierced his heart, and he was greatly distressed. He said:

The roots of his precepts were deep and firm, with the branches and leaves of shame and remorse, and the fragrance of his fame, the thick shade of great compassion.
My son was like a tree, trampled by the elephant of death;
Like a golden mountain, adorned with various jewels, my son, the king of golden mountains, with a body adorned with excellent characteristics, was crushed by the vajra of impermanence;
Like the great ocean, filled with various treasures, like a makara fish agitating the ocean waters, my son's great ocean was also like this, agitated by the makara fish of death;

Thinking of his son, he worried and pondered in various ways.

At that time, the ÅšÄkyas took YaÅ›odharÄ back to the palace and increased their respect and praise for her. They sought a wet nurse to serve her son, just as they did when he was born, without any difference.

The Story of the Old BrÄhmaá¹‡a Asking about Flattery (118) The Story of the Old BrÄhmaá¹‡a Asking about Flattery All cunning, flattery, and deception, outwardly appearing honest, inwardly harboring deceit, therefore the wise should discern true and false.
In the past, there was a brÄhmaá¹‡a who was already old. He married a young wife. The wife disliked her husband's old age and was constantly unfaithful.

When the old brÄhman heard this, he believed the words of his wife and held a great feast in her house, gathering brÄhmans.
Then the young wife had intercourse with him.
When the old brÄhman heard this, he became angry and took his treasures, wrapped them in his robe, abandoned his wife, and left.
Having gone far from the house, on the road he saw a brÄhman and made him his companion. At dusk they stayed in one place to spend the night, and in the morning they continued on their way.
Gradually getting farther and farther away from the householder's house, the brÄhman said to the old brÄhman:

Last night, a blade of grass got stuck to my clothes. Since I was young, I have never taken anything that is not given. The grass stuck to my clothes makes me feel ashamed. I want to return the grass blade to its owner. You all stay here and wait for me to come back.
When the old brÄhman heard these words, he deeply believed them and doubled his love and respect. He agreed to stay and wait.

That brÄhman pretended to pick up the grass blade to return it to the owner. Before going far, he entered a ditch, lay down on his stomach, and only returned after a long time, saying he had returned the grass blade to the owner.
The old brÄhman believed it to be true and doubled his love and respect.
The old brÄhman then went to relieve himself, and used his valuables as a deposit. This man then took his precious treasures and ran away.
The old brahmin saw that his belongings had been stolen, and he sighed in dismay. He also felt sad and distressed, and sadly continued on his way.
A little further ahead, he rested under a tree and saw a stork with grass in its mouth, saying to the other birds:
We should all have compassion for each other, gather in one place, and live together.
At that time, all the birds believed its words and came to gather.

Then the stork, while all the birds were away, went to other nests, pecked at the eggs, drank the liquid, killed the young and ate them. When the birds were about to return, it again held grass in its mouth.
When the birds returned and saw this, they all became angry and accused it, but the stork refused to admit it.

Under this tree, after a short while, he saw a renunciant, wearing a patched robe, walking slowly and deliberately, saying Go away, go away to all living beings. The old Brahmin asked him:

The renunciant replied:

When the Brahmin saw the renunciant speak these words, he deeply gave rise to sincere faith, and immediately followed him to his home.
In the evening, he stayed there and said to the Brahmin:
I need quiet to cultivate my mind, you may stay in a separate room and sleep there.
At that time, the Brahmin was delighted to hear about practicing the Way and was filled with joy.

In the latter part of the night, he only heard the sounds of music, singing, and dancing, so he went out to look. Having seen this, he thought to himself:
Among the myriad things in the world, whether human or animal, there is not a single one that can be trusted.
He spoke a verse, saying:
Not grasping at other men, returning the grass to the owner,
The crane falsely carries grass, the ascetic fears injuring insects,
Such deceitful words, there is none to be trusted.
At that time, in the country there was an elder whose household was extremely wealthy, with many precious treasures. In one night, he lost much of his wealth.
When the king heard about it, he asked the elder, saying:

The elder said to the king:

There has never been any deceit or interaction, only one brahmin who has long been coming and going. He keeps his body pure and clean, does not violate worldly things, and even returns the grass and leaves that stick to his clothes to their owners. Apart from him, there is no other person.
When the king heard this, he arrested the brahmin and questioned him.
At that time, the elder went to the king and said:

Then the king replied:
I have heard before that there are such cases of outwardly feigning purity while harboring deceit within. Do not worry. Let me investigate the truth.
Having said this, he immediately examined the case. The brahmin's words were exhausted and his principles were defeated. He confessed the truth.
Therefore, the wise one dwells in the world like a mirror, skillfully distinguishing the genuine from the false, acting as a guide for the world.

The Story of the Brahmin Wife Who Wanted to Harm Her Mother-in-law (119) The Story of the Brahmin Wife Who Wanted to Harm Her Mother-in-law: In the past, there was a Brahmin whose wife was young and beautiful, with deep desires and thoughts of licentiousness. Because her mother-in-law was present, she could not have her way and secretly plotted to harm her mother-in-law.
Pretending to be filial, she deceived her husband's mind, serving him diligently morning and evening, providing for his needs without fail. Her husband was delighted and said to his wife:
You now serve me and are a filial wife. My mother has entrusted her old age to you.
The wife replied to her husband:
Now my worldly offerings and support are meager. If I could obtain heavenly offerings, that would fulfill my wish. Is there any wonderful Dharma that can lead to rebirth in the heavens?
The husband replied to his wife:
The law of the Brahmins says that by throwing oneself off a cliff, into a fire, or undergoing the five heats, one can be reborn in heaven.
His wife replied to her husband:
If there is such a method, one can be reborn in heaven and receive natural offerings. Why must one be so diligent in accepting worldly offerings?

After saying this, the husband believed her words. He then made a large fire pit in the wild fields, piled up a lot of firewood, and made it burn extremely fiercely. He then held a great feast on top of the pit, supported the old mother, gathered his relatives, and the assembly of Brahmins all went to the feast. They played drums, music, and sang songs, enjoying themselves all day long.
When the guests had dispersed, he stayed alone with his mother. The husband and wife took their mother to the fire pit, pushed her into the pit, and ran away without looking back.
At that time, there was a small ledge in the fire pit. The mother fell onto the ledge and did not fall into the fire after all.
The mother then left the pit. The sun was already setting, so she followed the path she had come on, wanting to return home.
As she passed through the thickets, it was dark everywhere. Afraid of tigers, wolves, rÄká¹£asa demons, and others, she climbed up a low tree to avoid her fears.
It happened that a group of thieves had stolen much wealth and treasure. They were following each other, resting under the tree.
The old mother was afraid and did not dare move. Unable to control herself, she sneezed in the tree.
The thieves heard the sneeze and thought it was an evil ghost. They abandoned their wealth and scattered in all directions.

When it became light, the old mother was at ease and had no fear. She then climbed down from the tree, selected the wealth and treasure, and filled her back with fragrant necklaces, pearls, gold bracelets, earrings, and various wonderful things, and headed home.
When the husband and wife saw the mother, they were startled and frightened, thinking she was a zombie ghost, and did not dare come near.
The mother then said:
I died and was reborn in the heavens, obtaining much wealth and treasure.
and said to his wife:
The fragrant necklaces, pearls, gold bracelets, and earrings are what your parents, aunts, and sisters gave to you.
Because I am old and weak, I cannot carry much. I tell you to come, and I will give you whatever you want.
When the wife heard her mother-in-law's words, she was delighted and joyful. She sought to throw herself into the fire pit as her mother-in-law had done, and said to her husband:
My elderly mother-in-law, because she threw herself into the fire pit, obtained these treasures. Because of her weak strength, she could not carry much. If I go, I will definitely obtain much.
The husband, as she said, made a fire pit for her, and she threw herself into it, burning and rotting, and then disappeared forever.
At that time, the gods spoke a verse, saying:
A wife should not give rise to evil thoughts towards her husband,
Just as the wife who wanted to harm her mother-in-law ended up burning herself to death.

The Conditions of the Owl and the Crow (120) The Conditions of the Owl and the Crow In the past, there was an owl that had a deep-seated hatred for crows.ğŸ”½The owl waited until daytime when it knew the crow's vision was impaired, and trampled to death a flock of crows, eating their flesh.
The crow then, at night when it knew the owl's eyes were dark, pecked at a flock of owls, tearing open their intestines, and also ate them.
Fearing the daytime and fearing the night, there was no end to it.
At that time, among the flock of crows, there was a wise crow who said to the other crows:

Since we have become enemies, it cannot be resolved. We will end up annihilating each other, and neither side will be victorious. We should devise a plan to exterminate the owls, and then we can enjoy happiness. If we do not do that, we will be defeated in the end.
The other crows replied:
As you have said, what plan should we devise to destroy our enemy?
The wise crow answered:
You crows, just peck at me, pull out my feathers, peck my head, I will devise a plan to make sure you are all exterminated.
So it was as he said.
His appearance was emaciated, and he lamented outside the owl's den.
When the owl heard the sound, he came out and said:
Why is it that now your head is wounded, your feathers are falling out, you have come to me, and your sorrowful voice is extremely painful? What do you want to say?
The crow said to the owl:
The crows are hostile to me, I cannot make a living, so I come to seek refuge from my enemies.
At that time the owl pitied him and wanted to keep and raise him, but the other owls all said:
This is an enemy, he cannot be befriended. For what reason do you want to keep and raise him, to nurture an enemy?
Then the owl replied:
Now he is in distress and has come to seek refuge. Alone and solitary, what can I do?
So he raised it and gave it leftover meat.

As the days and months passed, its feathers and wings recovered. The crow pretended to be happy and secretly made plans. It carried dry tree branches and grasses to the owl's nest, seeming to repay its kindness.
The owl said to the crow:
What is the use of this?
The crow then replied:
The hole is full of cold stones. I use these grasses and trees to ward off the wind and cold.
The owl thought it was so and remained silent.
And the crow then sought to guard the hole, pretending to provide service, to repay its nurturing.

At that time, a heavy snow fell and the cold air was fierce. The owls gathered in the hole all at once. The crow took advantage of the situation and was overjoyed. It carried the fire used by cowherds to burn the owl's hole. The owls were all destroyed at that time.
At that time, the devas spoke a verse, saying:
In places with old grudges, one should not give rise to trust,
Like a crow pretending to be good, burning and destroying the bodies of many owls.

The Story of the Maid Fighting with a Sheep (121) The Story of the Maid Fighting with a Sheep: In the past, there was a maid who was by nature frugal and always in charge of barley and beans for her master.
At that time, there was a ram in the master's house who, taking advantage of an empty moment, ate the barley and beans.
The measure of the bushel was reduced, and the master became angry, believing that the maid did not take it herself, but that it was all eaten by the sheep.
Because of this, the maid always resented it and often beat the ram with a stick;
The ram also held a grudge and came to butt the maid. This kind of offense happened more than once.

One day, the maid took fire with empty hands. The sheep saw that she had no stick and came straight to butt the maid. Because the maid was in a hurry, she put the fire she had taken on the ram's back.
The sheep, feeling the heat of the fire, butted everywhere, burning the villagers, and spreading to the mountains and fields.
At that time, in the mountains, there were five hundred monkeys. The fire came fiercely, and they were unable to escape. They were all burned to death at once.
The devas, seeing this, spoke a verse, saying:
In the midst of anger and fighting, one should not stay,
The ram fought with the maid, and the villagers and monkeys died.
